Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

I'm not sure I understand your argument.
Are you saying that it doesn't work because pleasure is what reinforces behavior?
If so then there are many counter-examples.
Dopamine fasting is basically the same thing as asceticism. And it does work. Just because fasting in a cave in the desert doesn't mean some people don't do it. Sure, you might argue that they are actually enjoying the activity itself. But there is a difference between indulging in pleasures that don't require any kind of willpower or suffering, and pleasure with a longer time horizon that comes from being able to overcome suffering and immediate pleasure and the self esteem that comes along with it.
And it does make you tougher. That's the reason the military trains in shitty conditions, so they can endure the even shittier conditions of actual war and don't completely break down.
So in everyday life, what that might mean is that if you lose your job or your wife leaves you or something, I bet you will not suffer as much as if you were addicted to 10 different things in your everyday life.

Reminder that
>1 inch plates
>Chinesium racks
>Adjustable dumbbells
>Non metal weights
>Foam mats
>Pull-up bars
>Non-brand bikes
>Apartment "gyms"
Are not home gyms, the minimum for a home gym is
>Full cage
>Minimum 500 lb worth of calibrated oly plates
>Standardized dumbbells from 20lb to 100lb (no adjustable shitte)
>Proper rubber mats
>At least 5 kettle bells
>A peloton or concept 2

If you can't do this, return to planet fitness and start lifting.

>>69974786
Even stronglifts 5x5 actually only does a 1x5 of deadlifts every other workout. Deadlifts work best with 1 full working set, just do plenty of warmup. I saw great progress when first trying to reach 4pl8 doing 5rm, adding 10kg, doing 3 reps, adding 10kg and doing one. Afterwards I would do a couple sets of kneeling lat pulldowns and that would be literally all of my back volume for the day. This got me from 3pl8 to 4pl8 in about 10 weeks, and got me from 0 pull-ups to 3-5 depending on the day in the same timeframe, also my lats exploded so fast in about a 4 month period I got stretch marks on them despite losing 25lbs in the same timeframe. Deadlifts are absolutely amazing for strength especially in the noob phase, combined with a proper row/pull-up you'll have literally everything you need to build a ton of back mass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69974842
start at 60kg and add like 5kg per session, taking that extra month to build up will benefit you a lot long term and you'll plateau much later. Deadlifts can be surprisingly technical so taking the extra time to actually learn the movement can make a HUGE difference.

If you start at 80kg and increase 5kg per week, let's say you plateau at 110kg and have to deload to 90kg to progress. By the time the deload is over, you will be at the same point you would have been at had you started at 60kg and therefore had more time to build up strength. You will then proceed to plateau again sooner than if you start a bit lower, and will make less gains long term and potentially lose months of progress. Worse, your form could be shit long term and you stand more to risk in terms of injury. Just swallow the pride and do "low" weights for a month or two while you learn how to harness your whole body in a way you presumably never have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69974920
>>69974842
This also, start lower and stick to double overhand so you can build proper grip. It would be pathetic to be using over-under or straps and barely be doing 2pl8. Also, I cannot recommend chin-ups enough as your other main back exercise, if you can't do them kneeling lat pulldowns are ideal, normal lat pulldowns are okay, any sort of proper row that requires stability like a pendlay row or inverted row will do a lot too.

Most back progress I ever made was just this:
3x(5,3,1) Deadlift (increase 5kg per session)
3x8-12 kneeling lat pulldown (later chin ups when I got stronger) RPE 8-10
3x8-12 Hammer Curl RPE 8-10

Everything after that is overcomplicated and frankly unnecessary for a beginner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69974954
At least once per week, no more than twice. Really can't recommend deadlifting *heavy* more than once a week though. Second session doing something like 50% of your 1rm and doing like 10 rep sets and focusing on really strict technique can be beneficial. It depends a bit on how much you are squatting heavy since they are both hip hinges. At a time when I was new (bad mobility from no athletic experience) I couldn't squat heavy, so I got a lot out of twice per week, doing conventional one day and a variation the other. Once my mobility was fixed and I started getting an appreciable weight on the bar for squats, I couldn't do deadlifts that much because it was just too much fatigue.

TL;DR no more than once per week unless you're barely squatting at all (you should be squatting) then maybe twice.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

posts.com:
>>69941461
You're 175? Unless you are a manlet bonelet like me you're not too fat, so you have hope.
You don't need to do a hardcore training plan to get good in 2 months. The most important thing is to spend as much time on your feet as possible.
Do a joog every morning you can (they will get easier over time, you don't need to kill yourself and you shouldn't). When that is done just try to rack up as many steps as possible woolking. It depends on how strong your feet are, but this is what will give you the strength to handle the distance without getting injured. You don't want to get plantar fasciitis or other injury. Don't make the mistake of rooning hard then collapsing into a sedentary pile the rest of the day. This is how you get injured. Woolking a lot will also make you leaner and more attractive to the grill. Good luck.

>I got a pain in my lower right abdomen
Sounds like spleen pain, happens when your body can't keep up with oxygen/blood demand from exercise.
Make sure you warm-up properly, reduce your pace until you find a pace you're more or less comfortable with without feeling the pain and work your way up from there.
As soon as you feel the pain coming stop for a bit and breathe a lot.
Eventually it will start happening less

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69962585
>I was told to not restrict my calories yet because it’d demotivate me.
After covid I woke up one day to see I went from 60kg to 75kg.
What I did was to go running every day but it still didn't put a dent on the fucking weight.
I modified the approach and started running BEFORE lunch, it may suck a bit as you may run while kinda hungry but this will guarantee you're forcing your body to eat itself to get energy.
After that you eat a good, plentiful lunch. Then proceed not to eat anything for the rest of the day. Simple as.
Meal intake after 4-5pm should be kept to 0 or the bare minimum, you do NOT eat at night. If you get too hungry maybe have some fruit or one of those zero calorie bars and be done with it.
This way I easily dropped back to an OK 65kg within 2 months and have kept my weight in line since.

posts.com:
Fat cat and friends edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Motivated munchers who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

Roast my routine, i use low weight high reps/sets.

first
>20 min cardio warmup
>bench 5x12, inclined bench 5x12 and peck 5x12.
>french press 4x12, cable pushdown 6x12

second
>20 min cardio warmup
>leg press 5x12, leg extensions 6x12, leg curls 6x12
>plank 30s x4, situps 10x4

third
>20 min cardio warmup
>lat pull down 5x12, one arm row 4x12, seated row 5x12
>shoulder press 5x12, lateral raises 4x12

rest day and repeat.

>>69973128
I have a fairly expensive, high max resistance recumbent bike, and I also have a regular outdoor street bike.

I use both, and at max resistance, the recumbent bike gives me a far harder cardio workout than I get doing street biking. I don't know how accurate the calorie gauge is, as far as I know, its complete horseshit, but I know I'm working my fucking ass off. I can physically feel the difference every day when I use it, vs days where I don't, or when I use the outdoor bike, and its not even close to comparable.

I DO feel that, in combination with strict diet/better eating habits, and weight lifting, it has been absolutely essential part to my weight loss. It is also very convenient on wet or poor weather days, allows privacy and ease of use at any time of day, and allows me to completely focus just on the exercise and not worry about cars and shit. I swear by it as a form of cardio, and would probably only ever replace it with jogging or swimming if I could.

As a side note, though I don't trust the calories burned, a "wrong clock" can still show progress. So as I get more efficient and build stamina, I can see measurable progress on my calculated calorie burn, even if the number itself is not accurate, the ratio growth is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69973972
There are some very low calorie foods but they usually taste like absolute butthole.

Its because the "0 calories" stuff is usually artificial sweeteners, so you are pretty much drinking water + fake sweet chems.

Food isn't water. Food contains a lot of mass and shit, and most food isn't just sweet. There ARE, in fact, "zero calorie" candies, basically just lumps of artificial sweeteners in gel format, and they probably don't taste great but are probably passable.

For the rest of it, the food's mass has to come from somewhere, and if its entirely inedible content, its not typically something you want to be filling your stomach with. (Fiber lol) I've seen a few VERY low diet foods with like, 5-15 calories per serving, but they are mostly awful.

Also, carrots are very not low calorie for a veg. Celery is infamously low, supposedly, the act of digesting it costs more calories than it gives (IDK if true).

As a side note: zero calorie drinks are not zero calorie. They can legally call it zero if its under 5 per serving. All they have to do is calculate the serving size such that its 4 or less, and then they can say 0, and you will chug away. That said, I doubt anyone is having 200 calories of 4-calorie-serving soda on a typical day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69975488
>Which are what?
The rings accomodate for your build, which reduces shoulder/clavicle/sternum stress (Very big factor as some people literally can't do parallel bar dips due to their build, but they can still do ring dips). Due to this reason you can also go much deeper safely, which is generally better for hypertrophy due to weighted stretch. Of course since you need to actively stabilize the rings it's a very good exercise to indirectly strengthen your rotator cuff, which will reduce injury risk on other movements. And of course if you're strong enough you can go into the RTO position at the top, which shortens the pecs even more, something you can't do on regular dips.
>How are they more taxing if they're easier?
Greater absolute load is an independent fatigue factor, and greater absolute loads are necessary on regular dips due to the exercise being easier
>I could never do more than 12 at once so I didn't bother with this when I did them.
Then fatigue probably won't be an issue for you

posts.com:
Isolate it you dumbass nigga. Isometric holds are always good and you’ll get plenty of that from your pull days + farmer’s carries and any hanging, but you wouldn’t grow your biceps just through isometrics, would you?

They recover fast, so high frequency and volume with higher rep ranges is key. Hit them at least three times a week with isolation. Make sure to cover extension as well as flexion, so wrist curls (reverse as well), and finger curls. Avoid anything that causes sharp pain in your wrist, try different variations until you find one that works best. Do this for a year consistently and you’ll have bigger forearms than most lifters.

I'mma come at this from a different perspective.

99.9% of the posts here are correct - if you want to real-ass fight, do real-ass fighting sports. Muay Thai, Kyokushi, BJJ, whatever. What people are really saying, basically by implication, is that most forms of tae kwon do and karate are McDojo shit - good for making friends and light exercise, bad for real-ass fighting.

That said, you should also not discount some other arts, if only for fun. I regularly fuck around with kung fu/wushu (the hardcore performative stuff, not the shit done by old people in their backyard). Except for a few weirdos, nobody is claiming that shit will save you in a streetfight, but it's a fun time.

>>69970237
Kata was a means to an end they were a way to keep students occupied with doing formation drills and teaching the basics of the martial arts such as technique and flow. Kung Fu originated from a time when formation fighting was the king that's why you also see the Horse Stance practiced since it strengthens one's body to withstand riding on a horse as much as it does help with one's punching and pulling motions etc.

Kata in Japanese Martial Arts is mostly same idea, formation to teach the fundamentals to the students it used to be ONE Kata that contained all the techniques before being split up into different Kata, all this came from White Crane Kung Fu (Fujian), Sanchin Kata for example came from White Crane directly to Okinawan Karate and its still practiced in modern Karate styles that do Kata practice, think of it like a warm up or body conditioning Kata.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69965985
>is there a huge difference between an expensive fitness/smartwatch and a cheap one
>if there's any reason to buy a 300-400 euro watch. Is it just brand or there's something to it
depends on your usage
e.g. garmins usually have superb fitness / outdoor features
but you'll only miss those if you actually NEED them
like being on a 10day hike with no power / small solar and constantly having gps + maps is essential
a 700€ Garmin Fenix / epix is probably the only device existing in this form factor capable of this

Do you need such a watch for tracking your heartrate, steps and sleep?
Absolutely not!
A <100€ watch is fine for this too

You want more advanced workout / tracking options? Maybe more battery life and gps?
well you're probably already in the 300-400€ range

You need a watch replacing multiple devices? Like handheld GPS with maps, diving computer, smartwatch, running tracker etc. and track all your workouts / vacations like hiking, surfing, skiing, MTB, gym etc.
Yeah you're looking at 600€+, but this is replacing multiple devices costing more in total and even doing a better job than most plus having a bunch of additional features

Watches are an OK reference point but that's it. I mostly like it for the step counter and the number of runs counter for snowboarding.

Using the calorie tracker as a base for my eating, I'm able to gain weight and cut weight successfully, so it must be accurate "enough" to work.
Phone app that it pairs with is slick too.

>>69974186
>I'm a fucking retard
All good since you sound like you're legitimately willing to learn

Truth be told "cycle" is a bad word for what we do but it's the nomenclature that stuck
A better word is "course" since it simply has a start and an end
Regardless "cycle", "blast" and "course" all refer to taking a large amount of steroids for gaining muscle and SHOULD have a planned date for when you stop taking most/all of it though many people prolong their "cycle" usually to their detriment

When you decide to stop a "cycle" is when you either PCT or "cruise"
Again, unfortunately both those are not good words for what they actually represent but I'll try to explain them as best I can

PCT is for when you want to FULLY regain your natural hormones eventually without any drugs providing assistance of such

"Cruise" is when you just take testosterone or TRT and perhaps a little extra ancillary like HCG or even a SMALL amount of "weak" steroids like mastering
...though some people also continue to use a small amount of a particularly strong steroid called "decadurabolin" or otherwise nandrolone

I'm genuinely sorry if I confused you further but if you still have questions I'll try my best again to address them lol

/FAST/ #28 Anti-Flab Commando Ed
WAGMI bros

FAQ:
> What do I need to start?
- To keep your hands and food away from your piehole
>Beginner's routine?
Start skipping either breakfast or dinner, track your weight daily with a set weigh-in time. If the progress slows, go from 16:8 to something like 20:4 (four hours to eat) or One Meal A Day (OMAD). GET ELECTROLYTES

>I'm a hamplanet that's new to fasting, can I just jump into 3day+ extended fasting?
-Only if you want to burn muscle mass and lean tissue because you aren't fat-adapted retard
>How can I get fat-adapted?
-Do 16:8 or more daily fasting for about 2 months or do keto for a similar length of time if you don't want to feel you're starving or start losing muscle mass

> I want to do a longer fast, what do I need?
- Snake juice and peace
> What is snake juice?
- 1.5 tbsp salt, 1 tsp potassium chloride (nu-salt, no-salt), magnesium citrate/chloride (optional, check for epsom salts) to 2 liters of water
> I feel hungry!
- You shouldn't feel hungry after the first day, if you do and are new, try switching to keto macros and restarting the fast later

>Recommended macros?
- 70% fat, 25% protein, 5% carbs. Keep carbs below 50g total.
- P:E diet - 50% or more protein, <40% fat <10% carbs

>I'm sub 20bf, want to get lean, but don't want to lose muscle
- OMADEOD
>I'm sub 12% and not sleeping well
eat a tiny protein meal 3 hours before bed on your "full" day of the 48
>I'm gaining weight on OMAD
-You're FUCKING UP, weigh your meal components and record in cronometer (free). Add light cardio or standing or switch to OMEOD so you can continue to eat like fat pig.

>LIFE Fasting Circle Group (group fasting tracker for iOS & Android)
https://lifefastingtracker.app.link/Kf9tSyuowmb
Or Search "/fast/"

>>1. Roiding with even a tiny bit of responsibility is REALLY expensive.
I just priced out the following:
>running 500mg/wk of test enanthate for 12 weeks
>plus HCG so you don't deal with testicular atrophy (more than necessary)
>plus aromatizing inhibitors to prevent gynecomastia (more than necessary)
>plus PCT medication (more than necessary, enough for two cycles)
>all shipped domestically within the States
>from a reliable source
>with everything being pharma-grade
And all that will cost you ~$680. I can't tell you how much the three bloodwork check-ups you should get would cost, that's between you and your insurance, but not a whole lot more. Let's overestimate and call it $900 all in, including shipping. Is $900 cheap? No. Should you be able to save up $900 over the course of three-ish months? I don't know, $900 is just over three quarters of my monthly expendable budget, but three months sounds like a reasonable timeframe. Is $900 a "REALLY" large amount of money? Objectively no, not at all. Especially not for something that will verifiably improve your physique to the extent steroids will, disclaimers about diet and bf% aside.

I got a vasectomy 3 years ago, so I can share my experience. The procedure sucked, a lot of people insist that there's no pain and that they watched the whole thing but personally I was terrified of the prospect of having someone snipping at my balls with tools. My first piece of advice is that if there's a comfort option that costs a little bit more, pay for it. Future you will thank current you later.
I couldn't sit down quickly, with confidence for a little over a month. Some people have permanent ball pain post-procedure but that's a risk with any operation really.
Don't let people gaslight you into thinking the male vasectomy is no big deal, this is a common dogma in some prevailing ideologies, primarily feminism. This should be a personal choice between you, and you alone. I got it done, and I don't regret it at all but just keep in mind that there are risks.
My balls didn't swell to the size of grapefruits, I don't think that's a thing. You will have to abstain from cumming for a little over a week which I found to be tough, and also the first time you ejaculate post-surgery it may contain blood so it's probably best to do it alone in a dark room, not with your partner.
There's no correlation between test production and vasectomies. Simply put, the body still produces the same amount of sperm, but since your vas deferens are cut and (in my situation) one of them were soldered shut your body just reabsorbs the sperm cells anyway.
Goodluck anon! If you go through with it, have fun cream pie-ing your hot wife until one of you dies. I haven't worn a condom in years which is based

Self-hatred. Disgust at what I saw in the mirror. Sure, I had lost most of the weight I put on from ages 16 to 17, but A LOT of muscle came with it, so I was just a smaller fatass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69974636
OMAD is what you want. It's next to impossible to overeat on OMAD unless you're eating like a fat subhuman. If you can tame your retardation a little this is a better plan
>Breakfast
Skip it or have a protein shake
>Lunch
Lean meat/fish, potato, vegetables. Use low calorie sauces and get creative so you don't feel like an heroing. Make in bulk for the week. Stuffed peppers topped with fat free cheese with a baked potato on the side is like 600 calories per serving, tons of protein, and will keep you full and nourished for a long time. Shit like that
>Dinner
Same idea as lunch but you can swap the potato out for another good, cheap carb source like lentils, quinoa, sourdough bread, etc. Feel free to make something actually tasty since you'll be able to make it fresh
>Snacks
Avoid snacking in general. If you have to have something then fruit is a great option as well as something like jerky or Greek yogurt. I also like to make protein baked goods like protein brownies for before lifting just in case I feel worn down
>Drinks
Water, coffee, tea. Unsweetened. That's it. Have a diet soda if you're out with friends or something but otherwise keep it simple
